repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Jewish Orthodoxy, the traditional section of Jewry that maintains a religiously observant way of life based on a divinely ordained Torah and its laws, is composed of many groups that differ by certain customs and ideological trends. This collection documents Jewish Orthodoxy in its various manifestations through ephemeral publications created and distributed by Orthodox Jewish groups in Israel, the United States, and around the world. The materials range in date from 1914-2004, with the bulk of the material published between 1950-1995.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Jewish Orthodox Publication Collection, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Jewish Orthodox Publication collection was compiled from a gift from the University of Maryland in 2009.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Encoded by Noah Huffman, Crystal Reinhardt, November 2012
Accession(s) described in this finding aid: 2009

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Jewish Orthodoxy Publication Collection was compiled by Duke University Libraries staff during the processing of a large gift of books and serials from the University of Maryland. These materials, all of which relate directly to Orthodox Judaism, were separated from other print materials because of their ephemeral nature; most are small pamphlets, single issues, or small runs of a periodical or newsletter.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection contains single-issue and short-run serials and ephemeral publications from various Orthodox Jewish groups around the world, including Israel and the United States. The materials range in date from 1914 to 2004, and document a variety of subjects, including social customs, variants of Jewish Orthodoxy, neighborhoods within Israel, and Orthodox education. Jewish Orthodoxy is defined here as the traditional section of Jewry that maintains a religiously observant way of life based on a divinely ordained Torah.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the folowing series: Agudat Yisra'el; Rabbinical Council- United States; Beit Ya'akov; Children's; Kashrut, Shemitah; Ha-Mizrachi; Haredim; Hasidism; Conference of European Rabbis; Mitnagdim; Ne'emane Ha-torah; Orthodox General; Ramat Elhanan-Bnei Brak; Hozrim Bi'teshuvah; Religious Zionism; Technology and Halakhah; Yad L'Achim; and Yeshivot. Titles arranged alphabetically by Hebrew character within each series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Publications of Agudat Yisra'el, an ultra-orthodox, non-Zionist organization, which was founded in Eastern Europe at the beginning of the twentieth century in order to defend the Jewish traditional way of life, and has eventually become part of the political system in the State of Israel.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Titles arranged alphabetically by Hebrew character within each subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Publications of the Ha-Mizrachi movement, an orthodox Zionist movement established in Eastern Europe in the early twentieth century which aspired to combine the observance of the commandments with the return to Zion. Included are also publications of Ha-Po'el Ha-Mizrachi, a branch of the Ha-Mizrachi movement with labor and pioneering orientation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Publications of various Hasidic groups. Hasidism began as a religious renewal movement in eighteenth century Eastern Europe, among the followers of Rabbi Yisra'el ben Eli'ezer Ba'al Shem Tov, directed towards instilling piety into the life the Jewish masses. Over the years the Hasidic movement segmented into many groups, each following a certain rabbi who became known as “tzadic” and in many cases created a dynasty that continued to be the center of that particular group. The majority of the items in this section consist of publications of different Hasidic Groups.
